posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked:
Over the past few weeks, my robotics team has experienced motor failures due to high current usage. We are seeking information on alternative control methods employed by other teams, particularly regarding the use of Kraken X60 motors. Our current setup uses a torqueCurrentVelocityFOC control mode for drive motors and a dutyCycleOut mode with a PID controller on the RIO for steering motors. After thorough inspection, we believe the issue stems from internal motor wear rather than external factors such as debris or electrical malfunctions.  

If anyone has experience mitigating similar issues, please share your insights. Additionally, we are interested in understanding the predominant control strategies used by other teams in swerve robots to better emulate their practices.  

Thank you,  
Trent from FIRST Robotics Competition team 3669

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: The Kraken motors, including both X60 and X44 models, feature built-in thermal protection designed to limit motor power at specific temperatures. Both motor types were heated to these limits during testing, yet no permanent damage occurred to the motors. This outcome surprised me, as I initially believed that overheating motors—even without current limits—wasn't possible.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
Wow!  

So, any chance you can pull current logs (stator and supply)?  
20A supply current seems almost too safe; 40A should be OK on the drives.  
The default stator current is really high.  

Are your tires wearing really fast too? Having the wheels fighting each other will result in lots of power consumption.  

Oscillation (both in steering and drive) can also give you more power consumption than you should have, with lots of heating from braking after an over-shoot.  

Are you killing both drives and steers, or just one type?

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked: It has only been drive motors that have failed catastrophically releasing magic smoke. We’ve had a few steering motor failures though. I don’t feel comfortable pulling the logs because any motors that were getting hot already indicate the electronics are failing or have already caught fire.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Motor windings are typically where fault symptoms manifest, such as temperature sensors shorting to a winding and potentially damaging components like in the SparkMAX. Logs containing motor current readings, winding temperatures, and stator currents are crucial for troubleshooting. Additionally, checking if logs are maintained is essential for identifying issues. The wheels and steering function normally when the robot is offline, indicating potential mechanical failures if electronics are struggling to operate despite being repaired.

posts.name: Andrew McBride
posts.cooked: Cross the road will definitely want to know more about this failure. CTRE and WCP, which stand for Cross The Road Electronics and West Coast Products respectively, take great care to prevent catastrophic failure in their motors. Hearing about such an issue might lead them to conduct a thorough investigation, possibly even asking for a failed motor to analyze the failure mode during a root cause analysis. Additionally, these companies are known to be highly responsive via email and phone based on my experience.

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked:
Yes, extremely important - do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no other little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph. The text is:

Yes, burning up to the point of failure. Basically, the circuitry just starts spontaneously melting down and won’t stop until we power down the robot. It’s almost like there’s an aluminum shaving causing a short inside the motor, but we don’t even build our robots out of aluminum. We build our robots out of carbon fiber. It could be carbon fiber working its way into the tiny cracks around the motor end cap, but we don’t think so though. Fibers that small you would not expect to be able to cause a short.

Cleaned Version: Yes, extremely important - do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no other little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph. The text is: Yes, the system reaches extreme heat, causing the circuitry to melt spontaneously and remain inactive until powered off. It appears unusual since aluminum shavings aren’t involved; instead, carbon fiber might seep into minor cracks near the motor’s end cap. However, such small fibers likely wouldn’t cause a short-circuit despite expectations.

posts.cooked: So, cool/disturbing photos???

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked: We are working on getting the motors sent to CTRE. I was just wondering if anyone else has experienced the problem.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: Just to clarify, do you still need the same PDH again? Have you had any breakers trip or tried different ones? Also, did you consider stepping back after motor numbers 3 or 4? Approximately $1800 worth of motors could potentially fail permanently, and after the initial ones, especially if they're on the same mechanism, I think it's wise to take a step back and reconsider.

posts.name: George Horsey
posts.cooked: They have not encountered this issue with our eighth unit. These units were installed in the Mk4 SDS swerve modules with L3 ratios and have been tested during the season, two regionals, and championships. As others have mentioned, I am also interested in seeing pictures, logs, and the code once they are posted.

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked: Here is a link to the code on GitHub. We have set the stator current limit to 80A. The robot ran at two regionals before the motors started burning up, which is interesting.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: Do you have photos of your Swerve pods and their specific components? Please share if available today, excluding in-season updates.

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked: Yes, we have checked, the modules spin freely enough in all degrees of freedom that the resistance should not cause problems. We have never heard any stall whistles from the swerve motors.

posts.name: Trent Hekman
posts.cooked: We have experienced motor failures across various modules despite consistent power supply. Breakers have not tripped, indicating potential internal motor issues rather than overloading. Logging operations from currently functioning motors hasn’t identified the root cause yet. However, there is growing suspicion that carbon fiber components might be degrading within the casing, leading to component failure. We are considering reaching out to CTRE to explore if such degradation could explain the issue, which would necessitate improving our sealing mechanisms around the endcap.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: Frankly, should you run more motors before contacting and getting a hypothesis from CTRE? Is it worth considering the risk of burning more $200 motors?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
This exactly. The only time we’ve had serious repeated motor failure (using a Neo550 and a couple Sparks) was mid-competition, and returning to the field was crucial in avoiding shutdowns. We documented every operational detail during each incident. Upon review, the issues were:

1. Someone grabbed longer screws by accident, damaging windings.
2. Output ramping was off, leading to high-frequency, high-torque system oscillations.
3. Motors were improperly mounted, causing cantilevering and axial strain.

These problems formed a pattern similar to the current situation. If you recognize a potential issue, apply full brake pressure and begin minimizing variables in a low-risk scenario. While scientific analysis is valuable, given the cost, it’s more effective to address all system stressors simultaneously and gradually re-introduce complexity. Adjust currents, reduce controller gains, verify wiring—and proceed cautiously.
